awd_titl_txt: Enabling a Flexible, Non-disruptive Demand Control to Improve Grid Security & Performance
awd_abstract_narration:
As the penetration of smart controllable loads in the distribution system has been increasing, there has been a rising interest by utilities and ISOs to use these devices to improve the overall grid performance. Thermostatic controllable loads (TCLs) (heating, ventilation and air-conditioners (HVAC)) are rarely used for directly handling stability and security related issues. In this project, we systematically utilize the thermal storage of the HVAC systems to improve the security of the grid over various time scales (5 sec - 2 hrs).  While we will concentrate on enhancing system stability, the proposed DR aggregation and control methodology can be utilized for other services (emergency reserves, spinning reserves, load shaping, etc.) in a manner that ensures the customer comfort is not disrupted. The research results will be disseminated at relevant conferences.  Also, we plan to develop curriculum modules and short courses based on the research.

The uniqueness of the Demand Response(DR) aggregator with set-point control is that it reduces the control cost of DR imposed by frequent switching and reduces the likelihood of involuntary service interruption, enabling a more flexible, aggressive, and smooth demand control for a broad range of applications. A time-varying Extended Markov Model (EMM) is used in an online manner to control temperature set points of TCLs by taking into account the customer discomfort. The EMM is complimented by a time varying model predictive control (MPC) scheme to ensure effective control of TCLs to follow the reference power. The proposed scheme effectively broadens the set of available tools and resources to save the system at the onset of a severe event. The proposed approach monitors real-time voltage stability margin (VSM) and predicts VSM in a nonstationary operating environment and ensures that the customer dissatisfaction is limited while ensuring voltage stability via demand side control. The novel detection of the location and proportion of HVAC stalling devices using phasor measurement units (PMUs) & micro-PMUs within 2-5 seconds ensures that relevant devices are selected for DR control, leading to an improvement in the short-term stability of the system. Also, to ensure that the reconnection does not induce synchronization of TCLs, an MPC formulation using EMMs is solved to determine the effective reconnection scheme.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
The key outcomes of the project are:

  1. A technique that can detect the stalling of induction motors in the power grid from real-time measurements in the transmission and distribution systems using a simplified admittance model of the aggregated load model dynamics.
  2. A delayed voltage recovery characterization scheme using the analytical expression of the recovery times and an approach to leverage linear regression models to estimate the recovery times from offline studies.
  3. A mitigation strategy for fault induced delayed voltage recovery to ensure that the low voltage does not spread in the system by proactively and optimally disconnecting these motors based on topology, load proportion and stalling information.
  4. A framework for integrating the flexibility of devices in distribution (such as air conditioners, solar, battery storage, etc) at the bulk transmission level to enhance the long-term voltage stability margin of the overall system in a coordinated manner using set-points and customer comfort information from the demand response aggregator
  5. An accurate reduced order aggregated model of distribution system dynamics that can account for accurate stalling of the motors in the grid and can speed up the simulation by up to 10x with a large number of distribution systems. This speedup of 10x is significant as it enables the grid planners to expand their scenario set by 10 times. This is especially important in the emerging grid as the number of planning for scenarios is increasing due to the larger penetration of variable resources.
  6. A framework to estimate the impact of the distribution system on the transmission system using a co-simulation interface that interacts between pypower and GridLAB-D which is used to demonstrate the importance of distribution systems in the stability margin of the overall system. In some extreme cases, the margin reduced by 50% when accounting for distribution system.
  7. A convex optimization formulation that can estimate the extended unbalanced Thevenin equivalent of transmission and distribution systems using PMU and micro-PMU quasi steady-state measurements over a time window.
  8. A three-phase voltage stability indicator (VSI) that can be applied to the extended unbalanced Thevenin equivalent to estimate the proximity to the maximum power point. The VSI is 0 at no load and is 1 at the critical bus at the maximum loading. This index enables us to identify the critical buses in the system for voltage stability in an online manner for prioritizing controls to mitigate long term voltage instability.
  9. A systematic critical comparison of existing centralized Thevenin voltage stability methods in literature to identify the key properties necessary for practical implementation of long-term voltage stability monitoring by utilities and system operators. We show that the computational memory requirements of the admittance based long term voltage stability monitoring methods scales quadratically with the system size while it scales linearly for the Jacobian based methods. Thus, the Jacobian based methods appropriate for online voltage stability monitoring of large-scale power systems. 
  10. A data-driven model of aggregated induction motors (including the 3-phase and 1-phase motors and the distribution feeders) and the aggregate behavior of TCLs from extensive simulation data that can overcome the curse of dimensionality of large number of non-linear devices and enables optimization routines to run for large distribution systems.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Venkataramana Ajjarapu
por.por_txt_cntn:
The key outcomes of the project are:

A technique that can detect the stalling of induction motors in the power grid from real-time measurements in the transmission and distribution systems using a simplified admittance model of the aggregated load model dynamics. 
A delayed voltage recovery characterization scheme using the analytical expression of the recovery times and an approach to leverage linear regression models to estimate the recovery times from offline studies.
A mitigation strategy for fault induced delayed voltage recovery to ensure that the low voltage does not spread in the system by proactively and optimally disconnecting these motors based on topology, load proportion and stalling information.
A framework for integrating the flexibility of devices in distribution (such as air conditioners, solar, battery storage, etc) at the bulk transmission level to enhance the long-term voltage stability margin of the overall system in a coordinated manner using set-points and customer comfort information from the demand response aggregator
An accurate reduced order aggregated model of distribution system dynamics that can account for accurate stalling of the motors in the grid and can speed up the simulation by up to 10x with a large number of distribution systems. This speedup of 10x is significant as it enables the grid planners to expand their scenario set by 10 times. This is especially important in the emerging grid as the number of planning for scenarios is increasing due to the larger penetration of variable resources.
A framework to estimate the impact of the distribution system on the transmission system using a co-simulation interface that interacts between pypower and GridLAB-D which is used to demonstrate the importance of distribution systems in the stability margin of the overall system. In some extreme cases, the margin reduced by 50% when accounting for distribution system.
A convex optimization formulation that can estimate the extended unbalanced Thevenin equivalent of transmission and distribution systems using PMU and micro-PMU quasi steady-state measurements over a time window. 
A three-phase voltage stability indicator (VSI) that can be applied to the extended unbalanced Thevenin equivalent to estimate the proximity to the maximum power point. The VSI is 0 at no load and is 1 at the critical bus at the maximum loading. This index enables us to identify the critical buses in the system for voltage stability in an online manner for prioritizing controls to mitigate long term voltage instability. 
A systematic critical comparison of existing centralized Thevenin voltage stability methods in literature to identify the key properties necessary for practical implementation of long-term voltage stability monitoring by utilities and system operators. We show that the computational memory requirements of the admittance based long term voltage stability monitoring methods scales quadratically with the system size while it scales linearly for the Jacobian based methods. Thus, the Jacobian based methods appropriate for online voltage stability monitoring of large-scale power systems.  
A data-driven model of aggregated induction motors (including the 3-phase and 1-phase motors and the distribution feeders) and the aggregate behavior of TCLs from extensive simulation data that can overcome the curse of dimensionality of large number of non-linear devices and enables optimization routines to run for large distribution systems.
